Name: Harriette Wyman (Mrs. Clyde Wyman)
Address: Mont. Nelson, Sask.
Birthplace: Marysville, Iowa, U.S.A.

1. INDUSTRY BEGINNINGS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1912
   Where did you set up housekeeping? N.F. 3rd Ave. North, H.R.T. Settlement
   Where had you been living before that? Montana
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
   How far was it to your nearest store? 7 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Staples - flour, yeast, sugar, dried fruit, rolled oats etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
   In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs. at a time, a year's supply
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Around $3.25
   How much did you use graham flour? A little
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally? Sometimes, how far away? 2-3 miles, what year? 1924
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 80¢
   What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal? Very little, whole wheat? Parine? Very little
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? In the 30s for a short time
   How did you grind it? With a neighbor's feed grinder

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) dug well

How far was this water from your home? 15 ft. from house

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) from house

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Many shallow "dug" wells have dried up and shallow lakes and sloughs now dry. Many houses have cisterns. A few drilled wells with pumps also pumps in "dug" wells.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

- **Breakfast:** oatmeal porridge - toast - milk - coffee - cooked fruit (or pancakes)
- **Dinner:** potatoes, one other vegetable - meat (or eggs) - bread and butter, sometimes. The dessert was a milk pudding, or berry pie, or canned fruit with perhaps cookies or cake (depending on finances). Tea and milk.
- **Supper:** potatoes - some vegetable - eggs or meat - simple desert - milk and tea. Sometimes pickles.

---

Our pioneer days were not early enough to include shortages except during wartime when sugar was scarce and not rationing. It was "first come, first served".
